subject: Career
title: Imposter Syndrome in New Fields
description: A 60-second lesson on Imposter Syndrome in New Fields.

hook.text: Day one in the new career. Everyone seems smarter. You feel like a fraud. Welcome to imposter syndrome.

buildup.text: Psychologists Clance and Imes first described imposter syndrome in 1978 â€” the feeling of being a fake.

discovery.text: 70% of people experience it at some point. It's especially acute during career transitions.

twist.text: The paradox: the most competent people feel it most because they know enough to see their gaps.

climax.text: Reframe: being a beginner in a new field while being an expert in your old one is exactly right.

punchline.text: Feeling like a beginner in a new field means you actually made the transition.

quiz.question: What percentage of people experience imposter syndrome?
